Want to learn more about how we can connect more Americans to work? @ManhattanInst’s @oren_cass and @mercatus’ @veroderugy joined @swinshi on The Social Capitalists. Listen here ⬇️

“What barriers to opportunity can we identify and try to remove? How might incentives to join the workforce be strengthened? How might we more smartly invest in social capital to create new opportunities?" Watch @SenMikeLee’s opening statement from this week’s #JECHearing 👇🏼

Families with children predictably take housing selection seriously, as housing often determines children’s access to educational opportunities. Unfortunately, many Americans say they are prevented from moving to a better neighborhood due to high housing costs. pic.twitter.com/66zHMNRyz6

Public education has traditionally been tied directly to housing through school zones, which are typically designed so that students attend schools near home. Despite growing opportunities to opt out, 71% of students attend their assigned public school.

Schools can provide a platform for students and their families to build bonding and bridging social capital, and they act as stabilizing institutions that provide supportive social networks. About 90% of American students attend public schools, and 9% private schools.
Read Chairman @SenMikeLee's opening statement from today's #JECHearing ↓

“But those policies have, over time, reshaped the economy’s contours in ways that have left too many people out.” #EconTwitter #JECHearing

"At the same time, we free employers from the constraints of using the existing domestic workforce, offering them instead an option of using much cheaper foreign workers overseas or bringing the cheaper workers here." #JECHearing

"On each of these dimensions, America’s choices have been misguided. We overtax and underinvest in less-skilled workers, make them costly and risky to employers, and discourage investment in the industries where they could work most productively."

The labor market’s conditions dictate its behavior along five dimensions — demand, supply, boundaries, transactions, and taxes — and it can be improved along all five according to @oren_cass at today’s #JECHearing.
“If more and better jobs were more accessible to more people, they would be more likely to work. Better public policy can help.” #JECHearing

"Work is both a nexus of community and a prerequisite for it. Work relationships represent a crucial source of social capital, establishing a base from which people can engage in the broader community." @oren_cass #JECHearing

"Without work—the quintessential productive activity—self-esteem declines and a sense of helplessness increases. People become depressed—unemployed Americans are twice as likely as full-time workers to receive treatment for depression." @oren_cass #JECHearing pic.twitter.com/NXjRXeql5b

"We're concerned abt work bc connection to the labor force, the ability to support a household, & the opportunity to contribute productively to a community are fundamental to the flourishing of American citizens, the strength of their families, & the trajectory of our economy."

Meanwhile, residential zoning regulations control the type, size, and amount of homes built in different school zones and segregate cities by income within and across metropolitan areas.

However, housing’s relationship to schools is also a policy choice: districts have traditionally drawn school boundaries by neighborhood and assigned students to schools by home address, even when other options are more convenient or appealing to families.

Part of the relationship between housing and schools exists de facto, as students will naturally attend schools that are within commuting distance of their homes and research suggests school quality is partly capitalized into home prices.

Join us for tomorrow’s hearing on connecting more people to work. We’ll be livestreaming the entire hearing here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/hearings-calendar?ID=EB64E52B-510D-463B-B7D4-85B6BA1187B8 … pic.twitter.com/GgoCPMYZR5

#Chicago’s moderate residential zoning likely helps contain prices overall. The average neighborhood associated with an A- quality school has a median home value of $292,872, substantially less than #Portland or #SanFrancisco and around $8,000 less than #Houston.

The relationship between housing prices and school quality in #Chicago #Illinois is flatter than nationally or in comparison cities with traditional residential assignment policies. pic.twitter.com/0NQDxUAGv2
#Houston’s success likely hinges on its elastic housing supply which translates to more homes being permitted in the Houston metropolitan area on an annual basis. pic.twitter.com/rnQwyO8JQd

In #Houston #Texas, which lacks a traditional zoning code, the average neighborhood associated with an A quality school has a median home value of $300,359, around $81,000 less than the national average at that school quality level. pic.twitter.com/Zp3ZASbXfy

San Francisco’s districtwide lottery would likely be more effective at improving access if city residential zoning policies supported housing affordability, but the average neighborhood’s median home value is approximately $1 million at every school quality level.

#SanFrancisco #California exhibits a flatter relationship between housing & school quality through its lottery, which effectively charges 1 average home price across quality levels. But the price is so high that public education opportunities are inaccessible to many. pic.twitter.com/MdcE67c0ae

For those who care about access to high-quality education, Portland may represent the worst of both worlds: zoning which segregates housing by income & pushes up home prices + residentially assigned school zones that are less-accessible to families at different income levels.

#Portland, #Oregon pairs traditional school assignment policies with restrictive residential zoning. Home prices are significantly above national averages at every school quality level & the average neighborhood median home value associated with an A quality school is $555,096. pic.twitter.com/SCyOsfSiN0

Reforming residential zoning supports public school choice efforts by allowing a variety of housing throughout school zones, reducing prices, and improving affordability at every school quality level.

Since housing is the traditional gateway to public education, the Social Capital Project suggests policymakers deliver improved access to educational opportunity by minimizing residential zoning while expanding public school choice policies.

Join us for tomorrow’s #JECHearing with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome H. Powell. We’ll be livestreaming the entire hearing here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/hearings-calendar?ID=E1F7F9B1-57F9-41E1-A5B9-ACAB77784B48 … pic.twitter.com/CbgJ2g7nS4
Read more about how school and residential zoning limits educational opportunity here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=E4DD88F7-4D98-4FD4-B68A-20689CB4F94C …

#SanFrancisco exhibits flatter relationships between housing and school quality through its districtwide lottery. However, the price is so high that public education opportunities are inaccessible to many existing and would-be residents. pic.twitter.com/GMzfxzDWis

#Houston & #Chicago, major cities with less restrictive residential zoning, do a better job delivering access to high quality public schools than comparison cities with restrictive residential zoning, keeping home prices low and affordability high across school quality levels. pic.twitter.com/3rTsm5lgBn

#Portland OR features traditional residential assignment policies, restrictive residential zoning, and high, climbing average home values across increasing school quality levels. pic.twitter.com/vOrbHNOxtM

In a cross-city comparison, major cities with more restrictive residential zoning are less effective at providing high quality public education at low, affordable price. Below are some prime examples: pic.twitter.com/VTh0NyG3VU

We found that the average U.S. ZIP code associated with the highest quality (A+) public elementary school has a 4-fold ($486,104) higher median home price than the average neighborhood associated with the lowest quality (D or less) public elementary schools ($122,061).
Our latest report, "Zoned Out: How School and Residential Zoning Limit Educational Opportunity," explores the relationship between housing and public education.

When it comes to charitable giving, Americans have much to celebrate. In 2018, the U.S. ranked fourth in the Charities Aid Foundation’s World Giving Index. Giving as a percent of GDP has also risen, from 1.6% in 1978 to 2.1% in 2018. (see charts below) pic.twitter.com/vu4HRo5pY4
THREAD👇🏼 #EconTwitter https://twitter.com/JECRepublicans/status/1191368034239139840 …

Mobility comes with a downside: it may lead to brain drain from certain areas of the country, as the highly-educated leave places that offer lower returns for their skills to move to places that offer greater returns. 
Read more: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=581865E8-F994-44C1-AD45-48644F31E624 …

According to leading urbanist @Richard_Florida, being mobile is particularly critical to the career success of highly-educated adults because the industries these individuals occupy are located in select cities, rather than spread throughout the US like many less-skilled jobs.

Importantly, moving rates are not equal across groups. College-educated adults are and have historically been more likely to relocate than their non-college-educated peers, and they are more likely to move further from their birth states than others are.

Americans are a highly mobile people. Roughly a quarter to a third of adults in the United States have moved within the previous 5 years. While moving rates have declined in the U.S. over the last few decades, they are still higher than in nearly every other country in the world. pic.twitter.com/EGq8CBph2m

Read our latest report, “Reforming the Charitable Deduction,” for:
☑️ trends in charitable giving and their implications for civil society
☑️ the flaws of the current charitable deduction, and 
☑️ reforms to make tax policy fairer toward charitable giving and civil society

While total individual giving has increased over time, its share of total giving has decreased by 18%. Meanwhile, the share of giving coming from corporations, bequests, and especially foundations has increased. ⬇️ pic.twitter.com/7pMR0AUS56
The drop has been particularly pronounced among non-itemizers, those giving to religious causes, and lower-income Americans ↓ pic.twitter.com/oIrZ53xfFd

While total giving has increased, the percent of Americans giving has decreased, from 66% in 2000 to 56% in 2014. In other words, growing donations are coming from a shrinking share of the population.

Reforming the charitable deduction captures the spirit of the #SocialCapitalProject’s approach to policymaking. As noted in “The Wealth of Relations,” rebuilding civil society will require promoting subsidiarity, the principle of pursuing  goals at a local level where possible.

An improved charitable deduction would recognize that individuals and the institutions they support can often fulfill their purposes more effectively, and be more attuned to the particular needs of each person or community, than can any government agency👉🏽 https://jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=C3424D5D-659B-456C-8520-2813CD5D02BF …

The U.S. tax code has long had a charitable deduction. However, current policy has a number of flaws that limit its impact and are in need of reform. The decline in civil society only strengthens the importance of protecting charitable institutions and giving from undue taxation.
NEXT WEEK: Join us on November 13th for our hearing, The Economic Outlook with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome H. Powell. For details and livestream, visit our website ⬇️
Check out more options for charitable deduction reform here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?id=C3424D5D-659B-456C-8520-2813CD5D02BF …

One reform option is to make the charitable deduction more widely available. Perhaps the most common proposal for reform is moving the deduction “above the line,” making it available to both itemizers and non-itemizers.

Under current policy, non-itemizers are fully taxed on income that they give away to charitable causes (and itemizers are taxed on some of that income). This treatment is unfair, discourages giving, and weakens civil society.

The drawback is that the deduction doesn't apply to all taxpayers. That it disproportionately goes to higher-income taxpayers is a consequence of its design but not itself an intrinsic flaw. Giving ought to be safeguarded against taxation among lower-class Americans as well.

The after-tax price of giving (the value of donations minus the deduction) declines with income. Thus, even if low- and high-income taxpayers donated the same amount and itemized, the latter would still receive a greater charitable deduction. pic.twitter.com/8c0Ec8sRHp

However, because itemizers tend to have higher incomes, the charitable deduction overwhelmingly goes to higher-income taxpayers. Over 56% of the charitable giving that avoided taxation because of the deduction came from the top 1% of Americans. pic.twitter.com/g1rAxgGjrB

The charitable deduction allows itemizers to deduct the value of their charitable contributions to qualifying tax-exempt organizations, up to 60% of adjusted gross income (AGI). In 2018, the charitable deduction for individuals reduced federal revenue by $54.1 billion.
